qas.question: What makes up the bodies of vascular plants?

answers.text: do not produce ground-penetrating vascular roots

qas.question: How much of a non-vascular plant is involved in photosynthesis?
How are sporophytes generated in liverworts?

context: The bodies of vascular plants including clubmosses, ferns and seed plants (gymnosperms and angiosperms) generally have aerial and subterranean subsystems. The shoots consist of <a0_0>stems bearing green photosynthesising leaves<a0_0/> and reproductive structures. The underground vascularised roots bear root hairs at their tips and <a1_0>generally lack chlorophyll<a1_0/>. Non-vascular plants, the liverworts, hornworts and mosses <a2_0>do not produce ground-penetrating vascular roots<a2_0/> and <a3_0>most of the plant<a3_0/> participates in photosynthesis. The sporophyte generation is <a4_0>nonphotosynthetic<a4_0/> in liverworts but may be able to contribute part of its energy needs by photosynthesis in mosses and hornworts.
